summary: The failure type for non-TemporalFailure exceptions is incorrectly set to 'Error' instead of the actual exception class name. When throwing a custom error that extends Error (but not TemporalFailure), the type should reflect the actual class name like 'MyFailure' rather than the parent 'Error' class.
userImpact: Users debugging failures see incorrect type information, making it harder to identify which custom error was thrown in workflows.
rootCause: The code likely uses a method that returns the parent class name (Error) instead of accessing the actual constructor name through the prototype chain.
proposedFix: Use `err.__proto__.constructor.name` to get the actual exception class name instead of the parent class name.
resolutionDetails: The issue was identified as occurring in failure.ts at line 360, with a proposed fix to use the prototype constructor name.
